intro: Corydalis marschalliana var. pseudocava, commonly known as the marshallian corydalis, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Papaveraceae and is characterized by its delicate, spurred petals and clusters of small, pinkish to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine environments, thriving in well-drained soils and full sun. It produces slender, branching stems with opposite, lance-shaped leaves. Corydalis marschalliana var. pseudocava is valued for its ornamental appeal and is often cultivated in gardens for its delicate floral display.
